ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PREPARING PRIMARY SCHOOL STUDENTS FOR MAJOR EXAMINATIONS

     1.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister for Education (a) what is the rationale for abolishing the Primary 1 year-end examinations; (b) how will the Ministry address parents' concerns that their children may not be adequately prepared for major primary school examinations including the PSLE; (c) whether such parental concerns will result

Column: 1183

in greater pressure on the children as parents put them through additional after school programmes; and (d) what training and additional resources will be provided to teachers to help them handle the changes effectively.

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien) (for the Minister for Education): I thank Mdm Halimah for her questions. Assessments – whether tests or examinations – serve as useful and critical tools to provide information about teaching and learning to individual pupils and their parents. Assessments also provide important information about standards of performance for the individual and the system as a whole. Like all tools, assessments must be used judiciously. They are not an end in themselves but should be properly applied in the right circumstances with clear educational outcomes in mind.

 

     Summative assessments like term tests or year end examinations have their uses and at appropriate stages are used to measure pupil achievement for the purpose of grading, ranking or certification.  But they do not provide essential information about specific areas that the pupil can improve in that would help him better learn the topic or subject. In this regard, formative assessments provide richer information that can be used by the teacher, pupils and parents to improve in specific areas. For example, for English compositions, teachers can use rubrics to provide feedback to pupils on specific areas such as presentation of ideas, grammar and vocabulary. Rubrics provide a structured way of giving qualitative feedback beyond just an overall mark.

 

     Both types of assessments should be used as tools to enable every pupil to reach his full potential but in the early years of education in lower primary, the

Column: 1184

more important focus should be on formative assessment to build basic learning skills rather than summative assessments to rank pupils.

 

     Mdm Halimah asked if formative assessments would prepare pupils adequately for the PSLE. Formative assessments if used well can help accelerate pupils’ learning as they would identify specific skill sets or topics that the teacher could then focus on. We do need to train teachers in the application of formative assessments. Since July last year, MOE has partnered 16 schools to plan and prototype Holistic Assessment models and strategies at Primary 1 and Primary 2.  This prototyping has enabled us to draw key learning points from the schools’ experiences as we expand to include more schools. MOE has plans for all primary schools to be trained in the use of formative assessments for Primary 1 and 2 levels by 2013.  When schools are ready, they will move towards the use of topical tests and bite-sized performance tasks to check for understanding and mastery for Primary 1 and 2. Such use is appropriate because they are more effective tools to form basic learning skills compared to summative exams.

 

     Parents will continue to receive marks and grades in these assessments. But beyond this, teachers will also provide qualitative feedback to the pupils and parents to highlight areas where pupils have done well, and also ways to improve pupils’ learning.  In short, parents will be getting more and richer feedback about their children’s learning. Schools will monitor pupils’ progress and provide parents with useful feedback on the development of their children.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong): I thank the Senior Minister of State for the reply and I can see the shift from having examination-focused type of education to a more holistic education.  In my view, the question that is still not answered is

Column: 1185

whether the Ministry of Education has really gone far enough in this effort as we still have streaming at the relevant stages and we still have PSLE.  Hence, we will continue to see students, parents and teachers focusing on examinations.  Worse, this may, in fact, make additional tuition classes more necessary.  May I ask the Senior Minister of State for her comments on this because that is the feedback that I am getting from parents?

     Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien: I can appreciate the parents' involvement in their children's education.  In MOE, we see that as a positive phenomenon.  Having parents who are interested in how their children are being educated and brought up is important.  I would just like to re-emphasise MOE's move towards holistic education. We are trying to make our education richer and more effective for our children.  We are creating new and multiple pathways for children of different strengths and abilities to excel in their own areas. While parents are naturally anxious at the critical points of examination in their children's lives, we would like to assure the parents that the school system – the teachers, the leaders – has the interest of the children in their minds and will do their best to help the children.  The system itself will provide sufficient pathways for their children.

Column: 1185

PRIMARY 1 REGISTRATION EXERCISE

     2.  Er Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Education in the recent Primary 1 Registration Exercise (a) how many schools have to conduct balloting in Phase 2C of the admission exercise; (b) how many children gained admission to the school of their choice through (i) the parent volunteer scheme; and (ii) their parents' donation to the school; and (c) whether the Ministry has any plan to fine-tune the current system such as giving priority to those who live within 500 metres of the school.

Column: 1186

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr S Iswaran) (for the Minister for Education): First, let me assure the Member and, indeed, the House, that MOE provides sufficient school places in Primary 1 to take in all students and applications in a given year. There are in fact surplus places at the end of every Primary 1 Registration Exercise. Nevertheless, for popular schools which will always have more applications than places available, balloting is a fair means to determine admissions. The balloting situation this year is comparable to last year when MOE began the process of transition for primary schools to single sessions. Eighty schools or 45% of our primary schools conducted balloting in Phase 2C this year.

 

     The Member asked for the number of admissions in priority schemes before Phase 2C.  The Primary 1 registration framework has very clear criteria which set out the priority for admissions.  Donations by parents are not a consideration.  Those admitted under the parent volunteer scheme in Phase 2B took up only 3% of all places available, or 1,337 places, spread across 77 schools.  Overall, in this year’s exercise, over 98% of the children secured a Primary 1 place in their first-choice school or a school within two kilometres of their home.  MOE, therefore, has no plans to alter the current registration framework which has worked well to meet the diverse needs of the schools and the applicants.

     Er Lee Bee Wah (Ang Mo Kio): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State: for those who get in under Phase 2B through volunteer work, is there a minimum number of hours of voluntary work that has to be done?

     Mr Iswaran: Mr Speaker, Sir, this judgment is actually left to the schools to make.  The reason is simple: it is not just a matter of clocking hours.  It is the kind

Column: 1187

and the value of the contribution that a parent volunteer brings.  A mere measurement of the number of hours by itself may not be an accurate indicator of what they bring to the school and can contribute.  We leave it to the schools.  If we talk to the principals and the heads of departments, they have very systematic processes, they interview the parents and judge what the volunteers can bring to the school and how that complements the school's plans.  That is the basis on which they make the decisions.

     Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Senior Minister of State says the current system is working well.  May I ask whether he is aware that, for example, some who live in the flats immediately next to the school are not able to get into the school that they prefer, and end up having to travel more than two kilometres?

     Mr Iswaran: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I said, in the system we have today, we have priority accorded across the different phases according to criteria.  Within each phase, if there is an excess of places available, then admissions are based on proximity to the school.  That proximity is tiered.  In the first instance, those within a one-kilometre radius are accorded priority.  If that is exhausted and there are still places available, then those between a one- and two-kilometre radius are given the option.  If there are more applications than places, then there will be balloting.  Beyond that, admission will be for those in the three-kilometre radius and further.  That is a system that is fair.  To guarantee someone who lives across from the school that he will definitely get admission to that school would unnecessarily constrain the system, because, really, a one-kilometre radius accords sufficient priority for the purpose of proximity to the school.

     Mr Speaker: Er Lee Bee Wah, last question.

Column: 1188

     Er Lee Bee Wah:  Thank you, Sir.  For those schools that consistently see appeals from parents who live near the school – less than half a kilometre – will MOE consider additional criteria?  That means, for the first tier, it would be less than half a kilometre.

     Mr Iswaran:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Member is rephrasing the question that was asked earlier.  In effect, the answer is the same.  Basically, if you live within 500 metres of a school, it means you live within a one-kilometre radius of the school.  Therefore, you are already accorded priority.  To further fine-tune this may not necessarily result in outcomes that are good for the school or the community at large.

Column: 1188

APPLICATIONS FOR PERMANENT RESIDENCY

     3.  Assoc. Prof. Paulin Tay Straughan asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (a) how many applications were received for permanent residency in 2009 and 2010 and what is the proportion that was successful for each year; (b) what is the profile of those who were successful in their applications; (c) whether the fall in proportion of permanent residents (PR) is due to more stringent immigration policies; and (d) what are the implications of this restriction on PRs on the old-age support ratio for Singapore in the long term.

     The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, last year, the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) received a total of 132,200 applications for Permanent Residence or PR. A total of 115,900 PR applications were processed in 2009, of which 59,500 or 51% were successful.

 

     With the tightening of the immigration criteria since the end of last year, the

Column: 1189

number of PRs to be granted in 2010 will be noticeably less than that in 2009.

 

     The Member also asked for the profile of those who were successful in their PR applications. Of those granted PR, the majority of them qualified under the Professional, Technical and Skilled Workers Scheme where they are contributing to Singapore's economy.  Others who were granted PR are dependants of Singapore Citizens or are dependants of these economic PRs.  We will continue to be stringent in our requirements for PR. PR will be granted to those of suitable quality, are able to contribute to Singapore and integrate well into our society.

 

     An inflow of immigrants helps to improve the old-age support ratio by increasing the number of economically active residents.  Let me illustrate.  In 1970, when our TFR was above the replacement rate of 2.1, each elderly person was supported by 17 working adults.  Currently, we have about 8.2 working adults in the resident population supporting one elderly person.  If there were no PRs, we would have slightly fewer adults, at 7.2 working adults supporting one elderly person.  If we were to close our doors to immigrants tomorrow, we can expect the old-age support ratio to fall very fast.  In short, we would still need immigration to make up for the shortfall of babies and help ease the pressure of an ageing population.  We will carefully manage the numbers to ensure the quality of immigrants.

 

     Sir, declining population is a long-term issue.  It requires to be tackled well ahead, several decades ahead, of the problems manifesting themselves. Members will know that countries which now face declining population also, as a result, face serious economic challenges.  We do not want to be in that situation.

 

    

Column: 1190

Apart from immigration, we have made extensive efforts to tackle declining birth rates in our bid to address the challenges of an ageing population and to improve the old-age support ratio.  Measures such as the Marriage and Parenthood initiatives have been introduced to provide support to couples in getting married and having children.

 

 


While such initiatives have helped to cushion the decline in our birth rates, our TFR still shows a downward trend.  Unless there is a significant shift in attitudes towards marriage and parenthood, and we see improved birth rates, we will continue to need immigrants for Singapore to remain a vibrant and competitive economy.

     Assoc. Prof. Paulin Tay Straughan (Nominated Member):   Thank you, Deputy Prime Minister for your kind elaboration.  I have two supplementary questions.  The first is, with the more stringent criteria that we have now put in place, will this have implications on the flow of Permanent Residents (PRs) who are likely to take up citizenship and, therefore, what are the implications on the number of new citizens Singapore is likely to receive in the next five to 10 years? 

 

     My second supplementary question is whether the Deputy Prime Minister can comment on the ideal resident population that we are targeting in the short term.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng:  Sir, certainly with the new criteria, it will mean that we will have fewer new PRs compared to the last five years.  That means that, in future, the rate of increase will decline and at the same time the pool of people who are available and eligible to become citizens can also decline.  Right now, we already have more than half a million PRs and with the numbers we are getting, we will continue to see an increase of that pool.  But we are going to watch that very carefully to ensure that number of PRs we see in the future is not going to be

Column: 1191

significantly large and overwhelming the Singapore citizen population.  We have to watch that very carefully and, of course, like all policies, we will have to review and if there is a need for adjustment, we will continue to adjust. 

 

     What is the ideal population size?  We have to take into account the size of our country.  It is 700 plus square kilometres.  There is certainly a limit to what we can absorb new residents.  We have to provide space, not just for housing, but for industries, services, schools, hospitals, parks and for the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) and many other needs in order to support a population.  Therefore, while we do not have a target as such, to say that we must have so many people by year 'X', we also need to make sure that when we grow our population, it must be a sustainable one, such that we can support it.  Whatever size of population we have, there will be a trade-off which we will have to make.  What sort of trade-offs will we make? I think that is an issue that needs further study because it means trading off space, growth rate and many other possibilities.  So it is not such a simple issue as to say,  "we shall have X number of people and then all our problems be solved".  It would not because we are only living in the very small part of the world.  Whatever we do, we also have to bear in mind the impact on us of what goes on around us and what we can do in order to continue to survive and to prosper in the bigger world. 

 

Column: 1191

MALAYS IN RESIDENT POPULATION

     4.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Prime Minister in light of the 2010 Census which shows that the Malay share of the resident population has slipped from 14.8% in 1970 to 13.4% this year (a) what can be done to prevent the present population mix which has contributed to racial and religious harmony from further

Column: 1192

declining; and (b) what measures have been taken to attract Malay foreign talent into Singapore.

 

     Mr Wong Kan Seng (for the Prime Minister):   Mr Speaker, Sir, the share of Malays in the resident population, which includes citizens and permanent residents, has decreased marginally over the last 40 years, as noted by Mdm Halimah.  In absolute terms, however, the Malay resident population has increased from 298,000 to 504,000 over the same period.  If we only consider the citizen population, the share of Malays among the citizen population has grown from 14.1% in 1970 to 15.1% in year 2010.  Overall, they remain the second largest ethnic group following the Chinese.

 

     The key factors influencing the population mix are local fertility and immigration. While the Malay resident fertility rate has been declining in recent years, it has remained higher than that of the Chinese and Indians. As fertility rates for all ethnic groups have fallen below replacement levels, I encourage all Singaporeans to avail themselves of the measures supporting marriage and parenthood.

 

     Nonetheless, reversing fertility trends will take time and, in the interim, immigration is necessary to augment our local population.  We welcome immigrants of all ethnic groups who can contribute to our economy and integrate well into our society.  At the same time we are careful not to allow the inflow of immigrants to upset the current mix of races among our population.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob:  Thank you, Deputy Prime Minister, for that clarification.  Just one supplementary question.  Could the Deputy Prime Minister share with the House what are some of the challenges that the Government faces in trying to attract Malay foreign talent?  Moving ahead,  as we see the decline in 

Column: 1193

the birth rate of the Malay community and the difficulties that we faced in attracting Malay foreign talent, what other measures can be implemented to address this issue?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng:  Sir, the second question first.  The total fertility rate (TFR) for the Malay population has been declining over the last few years.  Many years ago it was still quite high and now it has trended down but still it is much higher than that for the Indians and the Chinese.  For the Chinese, TFR has gone to below 1.1; for the Indians, it is not too far from that.  For the Malays, it is 1.82.  It is still quite high compared to the other races. 

    

     As to how to attract Malay talents from around the region: there are job opportunities in Singapore and those who live around here know that we operate a different system, we have meritocracy and the job markets are available and opportunities are equal for all and people are rewarded by their performance, not by their particular relations with any particular group of people in power.  In order for us to make our place attractive, we are already different.  What we cannot do is to go overseas and target specific ethnic groups to come to Singapore.  And what we do not have are immigration consultants, like for some countries, openly going to other countries to advertise and help and facilitate residents or nationals there to migrate to another country.  I think we can read that in our own newspapers that there are immigration consultants giving advice to Singaporeans and facilitating their migration to other countries.  We have not done that.  We understand the sensitivities involved but what we can do and have done is to make scholarships available.  We have ASEAN scholarships, for example, and we have companies who are out there recruiting people and they are also interested in having a heterogeneous, multinational workforce because they have operations, companies and businesses

Column: 1194

in other countries.  They are also recruiting people by offering them scholarships.  So, we hope more of our companies can do that.  Hopefully they come here to work for a while and, if they like our place, they may want to settle down.  This is a place which they can think about.

Column: 1194

POPULATION AND TALENT DIVISION

     5. Assoc. Prof. Paulin Tay Straughan asked the Prime Minister what is the primary function of the Population and Talent Division and how will it complement the roles of the National Population Committee and the National Integration Council.

     6. Mr Teo Siong Seng asked the Prime Minister (a) when will the Population and Talent Division be set up; and (b) what kind of programmes will be put in place to manage the impact of Singapore's immigration policy.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng (for the Prime Minister):  Sir, with your permission, I would like to answer Question Nos.5 and 6 together. 

 

     Mr Speaker:   Yes.  

     Mr Wong Kan Seng:  The key function of the Population and Talent Division (PTD) is to formulate, coordinate and review whole of Government policies related to population and talent.  PTD's responsibilities will encompass three main policy areas that are currently under the purview of the National Population Secretariat, the National Integration Council and other Ministries, such as the Ministry of Home Affairs, the Ministry of Community Development, Youth and Sports, the Ministry of Manpower and the Ministry of Trade and Industry. These are: (i) population augmentation, (ii) talent attraction, immigration, naturalisation and integration; and (iii) engaging overseas Singaporeans.

   

Column: 1195

These policy issues have close linkages with one another. PTD's formation will bring them together under one management and centre of responsibility, and enable policy responses to be considered and addressed more holistically.

     The National Population Secretariat is working towards the inauguration of PTD at the beginning of next year.  As time is needed to work with the various Ministries on portfolio changes and the staff movements, more details will be made available when these are completed.

     Assoc. Prof. Paulin Tay Straughan:  Just one supplementary question, Sir.  Part of the PTD's aim is to manage the inflow of foreign labour and foreign visitors. In the fabric of Singapore society, given that the frustration with immigration concerns seems to stem from the ground, how would the PTD receive inputs from regular Singaporeans at the base level?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng:  I think we do not need to set up any special channel for inputs from Singaporeans on how they feel about the inflow of people.  We see that every day.  We hear that every day.  We read about it every day.  We can see that in our television news and newspapers.  We can hear that in dialogues and in sessions that Ministers and Members of Parliament hold with their residents.  There are enough channels of inputs.  In fact, we conduct briefings to our grassroots organisations and that is also a channel for them to give us their views on how they feel about such issues.  It is not as straightforward an issue as to say, to take in foreigners and then help to integrate them and so on.  We have to create the space for both groups to get together and for them to understand one another, and understand why there is a need for us to continue to keep our doors open to attract people to come and work here and support and contribute to our economy.

Column: 1196

ETHNIC INTEGRATION POLICY IN HDB ESTATES

(Impact on sale of flats)

     7.  Mr Viswa Sadasivan asked the Minister for National Development (a) how does the Government address the issue of HDB flat owners, especially ethnic minority owners, who have difficulty selling their flats because of the restrictions under the Ethnic Integration Policy; (b) how many such owners have had to sell their flats below market valuation; and (c) whether in such cases, the Government will consider buying back the flat from the owners at market valuation or offer a cash top up equal to the deficit, to demonstrate that such owners will not be unduly penalised because of restrictions resulting from a Government policy.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman) (for the Minister for National Development):   Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ethnic Integration Policy (EIP) was implemented in 1989 to prevent the formation of racial enclaves and promote racial harmony in HDB housing estates.  With the EIP, we ensure a good mix of residents of different races in different neighbourhoods and blocks of an HDB estate.

 

     The EIP limits are applied consistently across all ethnic groups, and are reviewed regularly to ensure that they remain relevant.  Just recently, we increased the EIP limits for the "Indian and Others" category by 2% points, to address demographic changes.  When the EIP limit for a particular ethnic group is not reached, there are no restrictions on the sale and purchase of an HDB resale flat.  As at September 2010, 86% of 162 HDB neighbourhoods have not reached any EIP limits.  In other words, potential flat sellers may face limitations in 14% of HDB neighbourhoods only.   And even when the

Column: 1197

EIP limit for a particular ethnic group is reached, sellers can still sell their flats to buyers from the same ethnic group, as it will not increase the ethnic group's proportion.

 

     Resale flat transactions take place on a willing buyer-willing seller basis.  The resale price is an outcome of the different attributes of the flat such as location, age, extent of renovation and the prevailing market conditions.  EIP is not the only factor that affects the resale price.  It is also difficult to attribute the resale price to any single factor.

OVERNIGHT PARKING IN HDB ESTATES

     19.   Er Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether the raising of overnight parking charges can adequately safeguard the interests of season parking tickets holders as well as better manage the parking demand at the carparks in HDB estates; (b) what data or studies have been done on overnight parking in HDB estates to support this decision; and (c) what is the Ministry's plan for other long-term solutions to resolve the parking problems in HDB estates.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:

     HDB manages about 550,000 car park lots in over 1,800 car parks.  With growing affluence, car ownership has increased in recent years.  This has resulted in localised shortages at about 10% of HDB car parks.

 

     HDB adopts a two-pronged strategy of increasing supply while managing demand to meet residents' needs for car park spaces.


     To improve availability of car park lots for residents, HDB reserves more red or red/white lots for season ticket holders.  HDB also groups car parks together for season parking to even out the demand for car parking and give residents more parking options. 

 

      In addition, HDB will spend $66 million to provide 5,000 additional car lots where there are localised shortages.  Where land is available, HDB will increase the capacity of existing car parks by extending surface car parks, converting vacant land to car parks, or building new multi-storey car parks.  Additional decks will be added to existing multi-storey car parks where technically feasible.  Work has already begun and 1,100 of these lots will be ready by end-2010 to address the shortages at 26 car parks.

 

     However, land is limited. HDB also has to balance the need for parking space with other needs for green spaces or other amenities.  Thus, it is essential to complement supply measures with demand management.

 

     HDB will safeguard parking lots for residents' needs by regulating short-term demand for parking lots.  The increase in the Night Parking Scheme (NPS) charges from $2 to $4 with effect from 1st November 2010 is one such measure.  The NPS charges were last revised in 1989.  Then, the season parking rates for surface and covered lots were $50 and $75 respectively.  The corresponding season parking rates today are $65 and $90.  Using NPS for 30 nights costs less than the season parking rates.  Therefore, the NPS rates need to be revised to manage night parking demand.  More motorists may choose to pay the half-hourly rate of $0.50 instead of the revised NPS charge and shorten their stay.  Motorists who need to park overnight regularly are encouraged to purchase a season parking ticket.

 

    At car parks with high demand for season parking, HDB would also remove the Night Parking Scheme and Free Parking Scheme on Sundays/Public Holidays to reduce competition for lots from visitors.

Another strategy to increase short-term parking turnover is the Electronic Parking System (EPS).  However, EPS is only viable at some car parks, due to the car park layout and high implementation costs.  HDB plans to implement EPS at another 300 car parks over the next five years.

 

     Parking shortages can also be attributed to the increased demand from households with more than one car.  There are about 36,000 HDB households owning more than one car, which is an increase of 60% compared to 2006.
 
     To manage demand, HDB accords priority for season parking tickets to the first-owned vehicle of each household on a first-come-first-served basis.  If there are season parking tickets left, they will be sold to the households with second and subsequent-owned vehicles (second priority).  The balance will be sold to residents who buy season parking tickets for vehicles not owned by them and non-residents (third priority). 

 

     We seek the understanding of motorists that in land-scarce Singapore, we need to manage the demand for car parks even as we increase the supply where feasible.

     The National Registration Act already requires Singapore residents to report their change of address to the Singapore Police Force (SPF) or the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) within 28 days.
